name: Rose Black Spot
description: A common fungal disease of roses and other plants, caused by the fungus Diplocarpon rosae. It weakens the plant by interrupting photosynthesis and causing significant leaf drop (defoliation).

stages.Initial: Small, dark-brown to black circular spots with fringed or feathery margins appear on the upper surface of leaves.
stages.Developed: The spots enlarge up to half an inch in diameter. The leaf tissue surrounding the spots turns yellow. Eventually, the infected leaves fall off the plant prematurely.

causes: The fungus Diplocarpon rosae, whose spores are spread by water from rain splash or overhead irrigation. The fungus overwinters on infected fallen leaves and stems.
risk_factors: Warm, wet, and humid weather. Poor air circulation around the plant. Susceptible rose varieties. Overhead watering that leaves foliage wet for extended periods.
preventive_measures: Choose disease-resistant varieties. Ensure proper spacing and pruning for good air circulation. Water at the base of the plant in the morning. Remove and destroy fallen leaves and infected canes.
solution: Prune and dispose of infected leaves and stems. Apply a preventative fungicide early in the season. Common active ingredients in effective fungicides include Chlorothalonil, Myclobutanil, and Tebuconazole. Neem oil can also be used as a less toxic alternative.
